content.label: This is a well made game! It has a good level of difficulty, good levels, and awesome gameplay. I’ve found very little wrong with the game other than a few cases where my soldiers didn’t detect enemies that run through their cone of vision. I’d love a multiplayer though. Either coop or versus (or both). Otherwise, awesome game. Definitely worth the $5.
There are too many good mods in PC, so please give me more mods on iOS! Thanks!

I really like this game. I have it for PC/Mac and when I learned it was available on iPad, I got very excited. The game is so much better (and seemingly faster) with a touch screen instead of a mouse.

But the translation between platforms hasn't been perfect. There are some rather annoying bugs —If you switch out to another app and switch back, the controls will be unresponsive. I have tried contacting support about this issue and have not heard back from them. (I did find a way to get the controls working again: pull down your notification page and then punch it back up.)

Another annoying bit is the planning and path making. You can erase 2 minutes of planning with one misplaced swipe that was supposed to do something else. The bigger path making problem is that sometimes they don't go away. You get phantom paths and waypoints. You don't know if those are actually there or just look like they are. Sometimes they look like they aren't there, but they are, and then you have a member of your SWAT team running around in little circles.

Should you get this game? If you like tactics games, the answer is a big, vehement yes. The only question is whether this app, or for PC/Mac from gog.com or Steam (Steam has easier mods than gog.com, gog.com has no DRM). This app has mods, too, but they do less and are sometimes silly. The PC/Mac game has lots of mods and making your own isn't hard, but they are far less organized. On the other hand, it's harder to completely mess up a unit's path with a misplaced finger or click. Big argument the App Store version: It's a lot cheaper, and its still the full game. On your iPad. Awesome.
Door kickers might just be one of the best values available in the App Store!
Mechanics seem fine, just boring as hell. Only played a few hours.
This game has some serious, long lasting fun. There's plenty of unlocks and some deep strategy elements. I can't wait for doorkickers 2!

I only found one complain I have with this game. It's the fact that there is no progress saving in iCloud. I had to erase the game because I needed to free some space and then, when I downloaded it again, everything was lost. That was a bummer. Other than that. Great game. A gem I didn't heard about before.

The controls are easy to learn and the variety of the missions is excellent. To me it feels like a live action version of Xcom that allows you to get into the meaty part of game right away. That is a good thing people.

A few minor glitches now and again, but an amazingly well-crafted game. If you like tactical squad command games and counter-terror, this definitely takes things to a new level. Yes, it's on even terms with Breach & Clear, and yes, there's way more missions. (B&C is still awesome, but this is a far better bang for your buck)

This game is perfect for me. There are so many small things that make this great. There are limitless ways to clear missions and I'm immersed in the strategy. I'm also happy this game has the ability to randomly generate a mission and building. Endless replay ability. I almost feel guilty for getting it at $5.

Full game all at once.  I have this on PC as well and wanted it on iPad, too.  Before it came to iPad I bought B+C, but I felt a bit jipped by that title and uninstalled it.

Doorkickers is fun, challenging with great replay value. Dozens of maps and scenarios, from fairly easy, to smash the iPad difficult.

I enjoy it a great deal.

This game is truly amazing. It was the first game I downloaded on my iPad pro and I've been playing it for two weeks straight.

This is gonna be a long review, you have been warned. Where do I start... Okay. I'll start with the cons.

1. Nobody makes mods. I'm not sure if this is the developer or the community's fault.

2. Injuries stay between missions in the campaign, which is frankly unrealistic. The only exception to this is the missions when you get stopped by criminals, and those are rare.

3. Bolt cutters are useless. Yes they're only supposed to be used in the city, but I'd rather just pick the lock or Manually breach it. Perhaps if there were more uses I'd be okay with them.

Pros
I'm going to keep this a bit more brief.

Realism. Everything is very realistic in this game, particularly the weapons and combat. Your dudes aren't invincible, they die in a few hits. And if it's the campaign missions they don't come back.

Difficulty. This game is hard, but it has a learning/difficulty curve that feels perfect. It's easy enough to learn the ropes and get pretty familiar with the game before it throws you into the harder missions.

Customization. The biggest part of this are the classes. The classes are the point man, a speedy class with only a pistol who counts on well placed shots to make quick kills on weaker enemies. Just don't get in a fight with some of the tough guys. Then you have the assaulter, this is your average guy. They use primary weapons and medium armor at the cost of speed and stealth. The next class is the breacher. The breacher is the guy who kicks in the reinforced steel door with a shotgun. Nuff said. The next class is the stealth class. They focus on silenced weapons and coordinated takedowns to avoid detection while sporting light armor, so avoid a major fight. The final class I forgot the name of. I'm going to call them the shield guys. These are the slowest and least armed class, using only light one handed guns while hiding behind a riot shield to protect themselves and others. 
The next part of customization is gear. You can select a huge number of weapons across all the classes. Then you have many sets of armor, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Finally there are special equipment items. These are utilities, from  explosive door charges or flash-bangs to teasers and... My least favorite part of this game, the bolt cutters. They do nothing useful. You open fairly rare gates faster, and they slow you down like an industrial quantity of lead. No joke, it's almost as bad as body armor. Oh and this uses up a valuable slot for things like explosive charges. Next we have the skill tree. Each section of the tree is devoted to another way to play. For example, you can train troops to double tap and follow up with a headshot when using a pistol, nearly guaranteeing a kill. Everything from making shotguns more effective against enemies in cover to close to body stances can be found here. The final part of customization is name and appearance. It's what it sounds like. I particularly like Ghost, Grim, and Spud as call signs. There are also lots of skins for your troops, though this doesn't effect in game sprites.

That brings me to the final pro, adaptability. You can viably make a huge elaborate plan or just kick in a door and hope for the best. No matter what your play style is you can still make it. Unless your play style is loosing.

That concludes my very lengthy review. Thanks for reading me ramble about how great this game and how pointless bold cutters are. I highly recommit you pick it up for just five dollars.
Great job with the game. Lots of fun to play.

title.label: Doorkickers Lives Up To Its Name

content.label:
I must say, Doorkickers is one of my favorite games for iOS. It has amazing dynamics and free form tactics, plus very little H.U.D. so your immersion would not be ruined. Any form of CQB (Close Quarter Battle) tactics is unlimited and at your fingertips. From checking corners to street battles, the possibilities are insane.
The way the game is structured is very creative, something that I was impressed of. It's real-time planning allows you to plan ahead of the game or plan on the go. The realism is also beautiful, very similar to CQB scenarios in the real world. From rounding a small corner to clearing a whole conference room, being careful and smart is the key. The choice of equipment and weapons is endless, involving real life equipment and mods to shape the game differently. Overall, I am very addicted to Doorkickers.
I've been waiting for some sort of SWAT game like this for a very long time. I am an avid fan of the art of anything SWAT-like. Doorkickers will always be one of my top games of all time for the iOS.
All I have to say is: "Tango Down."
